Message.Title: Microsoft Surface shipping forecast: 2012 & 2013
Message.Msg: Received a heads-up from a Silicon Valley friend re. component suppliers's forecast of Microsoft Surface shipments, for 2012 and 2013. In a nut shell, 2012 shipments is estimated to be 4 million units - likely all Surface RT, since Win8 Pro is slated for Q1 of 2013. 2013 shipments (both models) is placed at 14 million Google translate of the source article: ""Windows 8 Tablet PC in Surface leader, in 2012 shipments expected to reach 4 million units, with a market share of only about 4%. However, with the 2013 applications that support Windows 8 is a significant increase in wafer fab Intel, NVIDIA, Qualcomm and NB brand factory, have introduced new models of Windows 8 Tablet PC driven, the 2013 Windows 8 tablet computer shipments will opportunity to jump to 14 million units, the annual growth rate of 250 percent growth rate ranked the highest of the various systems Tablet PC. ""Windows 8平板電腦在Surface領軍下，2012年出貨量可望達400萬台，市占率僅約4％。不過，隨著2013年支援Windows 8的應用程式大幅增加，以及晶片廠英特爾、NVIDIA、Qualcomm與NB品牌廠，紛紛推出Windows 8平板電腦新機種的帶動下，2013年Windows 8平板電腦出貨量將有機會躍升到1,400萬台，年增率達250％，成長速度位居各系統平板電腦之冠。 http://money.chinatimes.com/news/news-content.aspx?id=20120819000073&cid=1211 (The 2013 shipment numbers are not broken out for RT and Pro.)

Topic.Title: Intel's Xeon Phi

Message.Msg: - Best would direct your not-so-good reading attention to Section 1.17 -- Intel Proprietary Patents which nvidia did NOT get rights to use. 1.17. “Intel Proprietary Product” shall mean Intel Processors, Intel Compatible Processors, Intel Architecture Emulators, Intel Compatible Compilers, Intel Compatible Chipsets, any product that contains or implements any Intel Processor Bus, and Flash Memory Products. For clarity, the presence of a Third Party Proprietary Processor in a product that qualifies as an Intel Proprietary Product in the absence of such Third Party Proprietary Processor shall not prevent such product from being an Intel Proprietary Product. All the good stuff, right? Jen didn't get any of that. Nada. -

Topic.Title: Intel's Xeon Phi

Message.Msg: - Perhaps you boys have never actually read the nvidia 10-K either. Here. Allow Best to educate you boys. Again. See page 77. http://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1045810/000104581012000013/nvda-2012x10k.htm#s81B563FBB83F13D5CC2E1FD897E872A7 Note 4 - Patent Cross License Agreement "On January 10, 2011, we entered into a new six-year patent cross licensing agreement, or the License Agreement, with Intel. Under the License Agreement, Intel has granted to NVIDIA and its qualified subsidiaries, and NVIDIA has granted to Intel and Intel’s qualified subsidiaries, a non-exclusive, non-transferable, worldwide license, without the right to sublicense to all patents that are either owned or controlled by the parties at any time that have a first filing date on or before March 31, 2017, to make, have made (subject to certain limitations), use, sell, offer to sell, import and otherwise dispose of certain semiconductor -- and electronic-related products anywhere in the world. NVIDIA’s rights to Intel’s patents have Certain Specified Limitations, including but not limited to, NVIDIA was NOT granted a license to: (1) certain microprocessors, defined in the License Agreement as “Intel Processors” or “Intel Compatible Processors;” (2) certain chipsets that connect to Intel Processors; or (3) certain flash memory products. In connection with the License Agreement, NVIDIA and Intel mutually agreed to settle all outstanding legal disputes." All the good, valuable Intel Patents. Jen failed to negotiate any rights to use them. -

Topic.Title: nVidia’s GTX 660 Ti is out still can’t beat AMD’s HD 7950 for the same price.

Message.Msg: "Impressive considering AMD has memory interface with 2x the bandwidth... and 1B more xtors per die... So let me see if got this right: AMD charges less for a larger die... NVDA charges more for a smaller die... So AMD has a larger die, a more expensive die to make, but has to charge less for anyone to buy it..." AMD doesn't have to charge less for anyone to buy it. They were already selling it before the 660 Ti was on the market. By lowering the price it gives people more incentive to buy it and push the 660 Ti out of the market. For the same price you get a better performance with the HD 7950. So, it's a no brainer to go with the HD 7950 not to mention it's more future proof. AMD is already trashing nVidia in the sub $299 market with their HD 7870, 7850 and 7700 for which AMD has NO COMPETITION.

Topic.Title: Intel's Xeon Phi

Message.Msg: - It appears that what Jen got to use from Intel was nada. Like a Popsicle stick -- but without the Popsicle part. Just the stick. Let's look at what Jen didn't get in the way of Intel Patents, shall we? 1. Intel Processors patents -- Excluded. 2. Intel Compatible Processor patents -- Excluded. 3. Intel Architecture Emulator patents -- Excluded. 4. Intel Compatible Compiler patents -- Excluded. 5. Intel Compatible Chipset patents -- Excluded. 6. Intel Processor Bus patents -- Excluded. 7. Intel Flash Memory patents -- Excluded. What Jen DID get access to is Intel's valuable semiconductor chip-making patents. UNFORTUNATELY, Jen doesn't own a fab plant. And use of the Intel patents is NON-TRANSFERABLE. So all of those Valuable process patents are of zero use to nvidia. HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA! Did I mention? Jen got a spent Popsicle stick. From Intel. -
